text.p: These are the leading stories in the Kenyan press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- A recent proposal for the reintroduction of commercial sports game hunting came from community ranches and not private sanctuaries.
- Parliament's deputy speaker says the government should demand compensation from Ethiopia for the killing of Kenyans in a raid by bandits last week.
- Kenya will benefit from a World Bank-funded project that is expected to bring under irrigation the majority of arid and semi-arid lands.
- A prominent Nairobi lawyer and his brother involved in a feud attempt to run over each other with a tractor and a pick-up truck in the Rift Valley.
- Panic grips members of the public in Trans Nzoia, as an armed policeman goes on a shooting spree.
- Thousands of Kisimani residents in Mombasa whose houses were burned down appeal for help.
- Police say a 20-year old man shot dead by police on Friday in Nairobi was not a student but a member of a gang of muggers.
- President Daniel arap Moi opens the last session of the current parliament today.
- The poorly-maintained city drainage system in Nairobi collapses within 48 hours of heavy rains.
- The president of the PTA bank Martin Ogang is accused of financial mismanagement.
- The United States sets up a monitoring base in western Uganda to keep track of the war in Zaire.
- The Tanzanian government says it will have direct contacts with Zairean rebel chief Laurent Kabila. ($1=55 Kenyan Shillings)
